 The word 'prejudice' inevitably causes problems because it's seldom used now in a neutral sense. But originally it simply meant to prejudge something according to conventional wisdom. Edmund Burke defended prejudice, writing that "prejudice renders a man's virtue his habit. . . Through just prejudice, his duty becomes a part of his nature."

 I'm using the phrase 'just prejudice' in a restricted sense taken from the political philosophy of Edmund Burke - whom I cited in an earlier post.
 
 What Burke is referring to are the customs, habits, and traditions that we acquire almost instinctively - or at least without previous rational analysis. Reason can be the front behind which lurk the preferences of one individual, and at best it represents the untested sagacity of just one generation. But tradition draws upon the wisdom of many generations and has stood the tests of time. So any institution or value system which has been subjected to the prudence and correcting influences of past experience should not be lightly abandoned in the name of 'progressive' idealism. 
 
 To clarify the picture a bit more, here's Burke's own words: "Prejudice is of ready application in the emergency; it previously engages the mind in a steady course of wisdom and virtue, and does not leave the man hesitating in the moment of decision, skeptical, puzzled and unresolved. Prejudice renders a man's virtue his habit; and not a series of unconnected acts. Through just prejudice, his duty becomes a part of his nature."
 
 I know this has been an unfashionable point of view for a long time. Since the Enlightenment, the intellectual history of western societies has been ornamented with the triumphs of rationality. And I'm not trying to nullify the great achievements of rational enquiry. However, I am calling for a sceptical attitude towards the airy abstractions by which rationalists operate and upon which they push through ill-considered social and cultural changes.
